title: 107_s2115
content: Title III of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include a new section establishing the National Center for Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response. The National Center for Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response is established within the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It is headed by a director appointed by the CDC Director. The Center administers grants to upgrade public health core capacities, including improving surveillance, laboratory diagnosis speed, workforce training, and secure communications. The National Center for Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response, established within the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, focuses on upgrading public health core capacities. This includes maintaining and deploying the National Pharmaceutical Stockpile, establishing a list of potential threats, and reviewing it every 6 months. The government will revise the list of regulated agents and toxins in consultation with the Department of Justice, Department of Energy, and Department of Defense. They will establish procedures for access, screening protocols, safety standards, and transfer regulations for these listed agents and toxins. The government will establish security requirements, registration, and a national database for listed agents and toxins. They will also train bioterrorism emergency response teams and improve the Laboratory Response Network. The government will expand and improve the Laboratory Response Network, organize simulation exercises for terrorist attacks, develop disease surveillance measures, and create response plans for terrorist attacks involving biological, chemical, or radiological weapons. The Center will coordinate communication and resources for response plans involving biological, chemical, or radiological weapons. Programs and functions will be transferred to the Center, along with personnel and necessary funds. The Center will coordinate communication and resources for response plans involving biological, chemical, or radiological weapons. Programs and functions related to bioterrorism preparedness and response will be transferred to the Center, without affecting their availability for expenditure.
